Hi Colin, that is definitely an interesting XOR network.  Several
other people have mentioned to me they ran across it with NEAT as
well. One thing to note is that people using backprop and things like
that wouldn't ever see this solution since they only use feedforward
networks.  So if you wanted to be really fair in a comparison, you'd
have to disabled recurrency (i.e. make it illegal).  However, I think
it only goes to show how important topology is when you discover
things like this.  Neural net textbooks never even mention this
possibility as far as I know.

I wanted also to ask you about your table (below) ...

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Take a look at this network that performs logical XOR...
> 
> ------------------------------------------------
>     neuron id="0" type="bias"
>     neuron id="1" type="in"
>     neuron id="2" type="in"
>     neuron id="3" type="out"
> 
>     connection src-id="0" tgt-id="3" weight="1.64327624043105"
>     connection src-id="1" tgt-id="3" weight="-3.3017311279049"
>     connection src-id="2" tgt-id="3" weight="-3.3025163810043"
>     connection src-id="3" tgt-id="3" weight="-7.44947553716588"
> ------------------------------------------------
> 
> Activate Fn is (1.0D/(1.0D+(Math.Exp(-accumulator))))   - this has 
> continuous output of 0.0 to 1.0
> 
> It surprised me because I was expecting at least 1 hidden node -
the 
> textbook example I have been using for tests has 2.
> 
> The truth table for the network looks like this:
> 
> 0    1    2    3(t0)    3(t1)
> --------------------------
> 1    0    0    0.83     0.01
> 1    0    1    0.16     0.05
> 1    1    0    0.16     0.05
> 1    1    1    0.007    0.007
> 

What is t1?  Is it after one more activation?  Generally in
classification problems, the right thing to do is let the network
relax (i.e. stop changing) before taking the outputs.  I'm not sure
you did that here, but if you didn't, it's possible if you let it
relax the values would be even more separated.  For more info on
relaxation in classification problems, see the following question in
the NEAT FAQ:

-How do I ensure that a network stabilizes before taking its output(s)
for a classification problem?  

ken

> Admitedly the seperation between true and false is small, but it's 
> there. From this we can see that the non-linearity introduced by
the 
> feedback on the output node plays a crucial part. So although there
are 
> no hidden nodes, for practical purposes the output node is
performing 
> the role of a hidden node.
> 
> Just though i'd mention it as a nice small example of how an
evolution 
> based search has found an unexpected (to me anyway!) architecture.
> 
> Colin.
